It is one of the Baltic states, and lies on the eastern shore of the Baltic Sea, to the southeast of Sweden and the east of Denmark, with Latvia to the north, Belarus to the east and south, Poland to the south, and Kaliningrad Oblast of Russia to the southwest. Lithuania covers an area of 65,300 km2 (25,2

entities.title: Vilnius
entities.description: Vilnius is the capital of Lithuania and its largest city, with a population of 589,425 as of 2019. The population of Vilnius's functional urban area, which stretches beyond the city limits, is estimated at 706,832, while according to the Vilnius territorial health insurance fund, there were 732,421 permanent inhabitants as of October 2020 in Vilnius city and Vilnius district municipalities combine

entities.title: Tallinn
entities.description: Tallinn is the capital and most populous city of Estonia. Located in the northern part of the country, on the shore of the Gulf of Finland of the Baltic Sea, it has a population of 437,619 in 2020. Administratively a part of Harju County, Tallinn is the main financial, industrial and cultural centre of Estonia; the second largest city, Tartu, is located in the southern part of Estonia, 187.2 kilom

entities.title: Baltic Way
entities.description: The Baltic Way or Baltic Chain was a peaceful political demonstration that occurred on 23 August 1989. Approximately two million people joined their hands to form a human chain spanning 675.5 kilometres (419.7 mi) across the three Baltic states – Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, which were considered at the time to be constituent republics of the Soviet Union.

entities.title: The Baltic Way
entities.description: The Baltic Way or Baltic Chain was a peaceful political demonstration that occurred on 23 August 1989. Approximately two million people joined their hands to form a human chain spanning 675.5 kilometres (419.7 mi) across the three Baltic states – Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, which were considered at the time to be constituent republics of the Soviet Union.

heading: Events
txt: Saddam Hussein appears on Iraqi state television with a number of Western "guests" (actually hostages) to try to prevent the Gulf War.

entities.title: Saddam Hussein
entities.description: Saddam Hussein Abd al-Majid al-Tikriti was an Iraqi politician who served as the fifth President of Iraq from 16 July 1979 until 9 April 2003. A leading member of the revolutionary Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party, and later, the Baghdad-based Ba'ath Party and its regional organization, the Iraqi Ba'ath Party—which espoused Ba'athism, a mix of Arab nationalism and Arab socialism—Saddam played a key rol

entities.title: Iraq
entities.description: Iraq, officially the Republic of Iraq, is a country in Western Asia, bordered by Turkey to the north, Iran to the east, Kuwait to the southeast, Saudi Arabia to the south, Jordan to the southwest and Syria to the west. The capital and largest city is Baghdad. Iraq is home to diverse ethnic groups including Arabs, Kurds, Turkmens, Assyrians, Yazidis, Shabakis, Armenians, Mandaeans, Circassians, Sab

entities.title: Western world
entities.description: The Western world, also known as the West, refers to various regions, nations and states, depending on the context, most often consisting of the majority of Europe, the Americas, and Australasia. The Western world is also known as the Occident, in contrast to the Orient or Eastern world. It might mean the Northern half of the North–South divide.

entities.title: Gulf War
entities.description: The Gulf War was a war waged by coalition forces from 35 nations led by the United States against Iraq in response to Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait arising from oil pricing and production disputes. It was codenamed Operation Desert Shield for operations leading to the buildup of troops and defense of Saudi Arabia and Operation Desert Storm in its combat phase.

heading: Events
txt: Armenia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.

entities.title: Soviet Union
entities.description: The Soviet Union, officially the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), was a federal socialist state in Northern Eurasia that existed from 1922 to 1991. Nominally a union of multiple national Soviet republics, in practice its government and economy were highly centralized until its final years. It was a one-party state prior to 1990 governed by Communist Party of the Soviet Union, with Mosco

heading: Events
txt: West and East Germany announce that they will reunite on October 3.

heading: Events
txt: The World Wide Web is opened to the public.

entities.title: World Wide Web
entities.description: The World Wide Web (WWW), commonly known as the Web, is an information system where documents and other web resources are identified by Uniform Resource Locators, which may be interlinked by hyperlinks, and are accessible over the Internet. The resources of the Web are transferred via the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), may be accessed by users by a software application called a web browser, a

heading: Events
txt: Eugene Bullard, the only African American pilot in World War I, is posthumously commissioned as Second Lieutenant in the United States Air Force.

entities.title: Eugene Bullard
entities.description: Eugene Jacques Bullard, born Eugene James Bullard, was the first black American military pilot. Bullard, who flew for France, was one of the few black combat pilots during World War I, along with William Robinson Clarke, a Jamaican who flew for the Royal Flying Corps, Domenico Mondelli from Italy and Ahmet Ali Çelikten of the Ottoman Empire. Also a boxer and a jazz musician, he was called "L'Hiron

entities.title: African Americans
entities.description: African Americans are an ethnic group of Americans with total or partial ancestry from any of the black racial groups of Africa. The term African American generally denotes descendants of enslaved black people who are from the United States, while some recent black immigrants or their children may also come to identify as African-American or may identify differently.

entities.title: Second Lieutenant
entities.description: Second lieutenant is a junior commissioned officer military rank in many armed forces, comparable to NATO OF-1a rank.

entities.title: United States Air Force
entities.description: The United States Air Force (USAF) is the air service branch of the United States Armed Forces. It is one of the eight U.S. uniformed services. Initially formed as a part of the United States Army on 1 August 1907, the USAF was established as a separate branch of the U.S. Armed Forces on 18 September 1947 with the passing of the National Security Act of 1947. It is the second youngest branch of th

heading: Events
txt: Gulf Air Flight 072 crashes into the Persian Gulf near Manama, Bahrain, killing 143.

entities.title: Gulf Air Flight 072
entities.description: Gulf Air Flight 072 (GF072/GFA072) was a scheduled international passenger flight from Cairo International Airport in Egypt to Bahrain International Airport in Bahrain, operated by Gulf Air. On 23 August 2000 at 19:30 Arabia Standard Time (UTC+3), the Airbus A320 crashed minutes after executing a go-around upon failed attempt to land on Runway 12. The flight crew suffered from spatial disorientati

entities.title: Persian Gulf
entities.description: The Persian Gulf is a mediterranean sea in Western Asia. The body of water is an extension of the Indian Ocean through the Strait of Hormuz and lies between Iran to the northeast and the Arabian Peninsula to the southwest. The Shatt al-Arab river delta forms the northwest shoreline.

entities.title: Manama, Bahrain
entities.description: Manama is the capital and largest city of Bahrain, with an approximate population of 200,000 people as of 2020. Long an important trading center in the Persian Gulf, Manama is home to a very diverse population. After periods of Portuguese and Persian control and invasions from the ruling dynasties of Saudi Arabia and Oman, Bahrain established itself as an independent nation in 1971 after a period

heading: Events
txt: Natascha Kampusch, who had been abducted at the age of ten, escapes from her captor Wolfgang Přiklopil, after eight years of captivity.

entities.title: Natascha Kampusch
entities.description: Natascha Maria Kampusch is an Austrian woman who was abducted at the age of 10 on 2 March 1998 and held in a secret cellar by her kidnapper Wolfgang Přiklopil for more than eight years, until she escaped on 23 August 2006. She has written a book about her ordeal, 3,096 Days (2010), upon which the 2013 German film 3096 Days is based.

entities.title: Wolfgang Přiklopil
entities.description: Natascha Maria Kampusch is an Austrian woman who was abducted at the age of 10 on 2 March 1998 and held in a secret cellar by her kidnapper Wolfgang Přiklopil for more than eight years, until she escaped on 23 August 2006. She has written a book about her ordeal, 3,096 Days (2010), upon which the 2013 German film 3096 Days is based.

heading: Events
txt: The skeletal remains of Russia's last royal family members Alexei Nikolaevich, Tsarevich of Russia, and his sister Grand Duchess Anastasia are discovered near Yekaterinburg, Russia.

entities.title: Alexei Nikolaevich, Tsarevich of Russia
entities.description: Alexei Nikolaevich of the House of Romanov, was the last Tsesarevich and heir apparent to the throne of the Russian Empire. He was the youngest child and only son of Emperor Nicholas II and Empress Alexandra Feodorovna. He was born with haemophilia, which his parents tried treating with the methods of faith healer Grigori Rasputin.

entities.title: Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia
entities.description: Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia  was the youngest daughter of Tsar Nicholas II, the last sovereign of Imperial Russia, and his wife, Tsarina Alexandra Feodorovna.

entities.title: Yekaterinburg
entities.description: Yekaterinburg, alternatively romanized Ekaterinburg, formerly known as Sverdlovsk, is the largest city and the administrative centre of Sverdlovsk Oblast and the Ural Federal District, Russia. The city is located on the Iset River in Western Siberia, with a population of roughly 1.5 million residents, up to 2.2 million residents in the urban agglomeration. Yekaterinburg is the fourth-largest city

heading: Events
txt: A magnitude 5.8 (class: moderate) earthquake occurs in Virginia. Damage occurs to monuments and structures in Washington D.C. and the resulted damage is estimated at $200 million–$300 million USD.

entities.title: 2011 Virginia earthquake
entities.description: On August 23, 2011, a magnitude 5.8 earthquake hit the Piedmont region of the U.S. state of Virginia at 1:51:04 p.m. EDT. The epicenter, in Louisa County, was 38 mi (61 km) northwest of Richmond and 5 mi (8 km) south-southwest of the town of Mineral. It was an intraplate earthquake with a maximum perceived intensity of VII on the Mercalli intensity scale. Several aftershocks, ranging up to 4.5 Mw

entities.title: Virginia
entities.description: Virginia, officially the Commonwealth of Virginia, is a state in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeastern regions of the United States, between the Atlantic Coast and the Appalachian Mountains. The geography and climate of the Commonwealth are shaped by the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Chesapeake Bay, which provide habitat for much of its flora and fauna. The capital of the Commonwealth is Richmond; Virg

heading: Events
txt: Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi is overthrown after the National Transitional Council forces take control of Bab al-Azizia compound during the Libyan Civil War.

entities.title: National Transitional Council
entities.description: The National Transitional Council of Libya, sometimes known as the Transitional National Council, was the de facto government of Libya for a period during and after the Libyan Civil War, in which rebel forces overthrew the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya of Muammar Gaddafi. The NTC governed Libya for a period of ten months after the end of the war, holding elections to a General National Congress on 7 July

entities.title: Bab al-Azizia
entities.description: Bab al-Azizia, "The Splendid Gate", is a military barracks and compound situated in the southern suburbs of Tripoli, the capital of Libya. It served as the main base for the Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi until its capture by anti-Gaddafi forces on 23 August 2011, during the Battle of Tripoli in the Libyan Civil War.

entities.title: Libyan Civil War (2011)
entities.description: The First Libyan Civil War was an armed conflict in 2011 in the North African country of Libya which was fought between forces which were loyal to Colonel Muammar Gaddafi and foreign supported groups which were seeking to oust his government. It erupted with the Libyan Revolution, also known as the 17 February Revolution. The war was preceded by protests in Zawiya on 8 August 2009 and finally igni

heading: Events
txt: A hot-air balloon crashes near the Slovenian capital of Ljubljana, killing six people and injuring 28 others.

entities.title: 2012 Ljubljana Marshes hot air balloon crash
entities.description: On 23 August 2012, a hot air balloon on a commercial sightseeing flight crashed in stormy weather on the Ljubljana Marshes in central Slovenia, killing 6 of the 32 people on board.

entities.title: Ljubljana
entities.description: Ljubljana is the capital and largest city of Slovenia. It has been the cultural, educational, economic, political and administrative centre.

heading: Events
txt: A riot at the Palmasola prison complex in Santa Cruz, Bolivia kills 31 people.

entities.title: 2013 Palmasola prison riot
entities.description: On August 23, 2013, a prison riot broke out at Palmasola, a maximum-security prison in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. The riot started when members of one cell block attacked a rival gang in another, using propane tanks as flame throwers. Thirty-one people were killed, including an 18-month-old child who was living at the prison. Thirty-seven others were seriously injured. The riot led to calls for reform i

entities.title: Palmasola
entities.description: Centro de Rehabilitación Santa Cruz "Palmasola" is a maximum security prison in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. It is Bolivia's largest prison and holds about 3,500 prisoners. Like many prisons in Latin America, guards exhibit minimal control over what happens within the prison, leading it to being described as a "prison town". Guards instead concentrate only on securing the perimeter of the facility. Accor

entities.title: Santa Cruz de la Sierra
entities.description: Santa Cruz de la Sierra, commonly known as Santa Cruz, is the largest city in Bolivia and the capital of the Santa Cruz department.

heading: Births
txt: Jo Gwang-jo, Korean philosopher (d. 1520)

entities.title: Jo Gwang-jo
entities.description: Jo Gwangjo, also often called by his pen name Jeong-am, was Korean Neo-Confucian scholar who pursued radical reforms during the reign of Jungjong of Joseon in the early 16th century.

heading: Births
txt: Sigismund von Herberstein, Slovenian historian and diplomat (d. 1566)

entities.title: Sigismund von Herberstein
entities.description: Siegmund (Sigismund) Freiherr von Herberstein was a Carniolan diplomat, writer, historian and member of the Holy Roman Empire Imperial Council. He was most noted for his extensive writing on the geography, history and customs of Russia, and contributed greatly to early Western European knowledge of that area.

heading: Births
txt: Miguel da Paz, Prince of Portugal (d. 1500)

entities.title: Miguel da Paz, Prince of Portugal
entities.description: Miguel da Paz, Hereditary Prince of Portugal and Prince of Asturias was a Portuguese royal prince, son of King Manuel I of Portugal and his first wife, Isabella of Aragon, Princess of Asturias (1470-1498).

heading: Births
txt: François Hotman, French lawyer and jurist (d. 1590)

entities.title: François Hotman
entities.description: François Hotman was a French Protestant lawyer and writer, associated with the legal humanists and with the monarchomaques, who struggled against absolute monarchy. His first name is often written 'Francis' in English. His surname is Latinized by himself as Hotomanus, by others as Hotomannus and Hottomannus. He has been called "one of the first modern revolutionaries".

heading: Births
txt: Thomas Dempster, Scottish scholar and historian (d. 1625)

entities.title: Thomas Dempster
entities.description: Thomas Dempster was a Scottish scholar and historian. Born into the aristocracy in Aberdeenshire, which comprises regions of both the Scottish highlands and the Scottish lowlands, he was sent abroad as a youth for his education. The Dempsters were Catholic in an increasingly Protestant country and had a reputation for being quarrelsome. Thomas' brother James, outlawed for an attack on his father,

heading: Births
txt: Stanisław Lubieniecki, Polish astronomer, theologian, and historian (d. 1675)

entities.title: Stanisław Lubieniecki
entities.description: Stanisław Lubieniecki was a Polish Socinian theologist, historian, astronomer, and writer. He is the eponym of the lunar crater Lubiniezky.

heading: Births
txt: Abraham Yates, Jr., American lawyer and civil servant (d. 1796)

entities.title: Abraham Yates, Jr.
entities.description: Abraham Yates Jr. was an American lawyer, civil servant, and pamphleteer from Albany, New York.

heading: Births
txt: Jean-François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse, French admiral and explorer (d. 1788)

entities.title: Jean-François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse
entities.description: Jean François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse was a French naval officer and explorer whose expedition vanished in Oceania.

heading: Births
txt: Louis XVI of France (d. 1793)

entities.title: Louis XVI of France
entities.description: Louis XVI was the last king of France before the fall of the monarchy during the French Revolution. He was referred to as Citizen Louis Capet during the four months just before he was executed by guillotine. In 1765, upon the death of his father, Louis, Dauphin of France, he became the new Dauphin. Upon his grandfather Louis XV's death on 10 May 1774, he assumed the title King of France and Navarr

heading: Births
txt: Georges Cuvier, French biologist and academic (d. 1832)

entities.title: Georges Cuvier
entities.description: Jean Léopold Nicolas Frédéric, Baron Cuvier, known as Georges Cuvier, was a French naturalist and zoologist, sometimes referred to as the "founding father of paleontology". entities.description: The Diocese of Dresden–Meissen is a Diocese of Catholic Church in Germany with its seat in Dresden. It is suffragan to the Archdiocese of Berlin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Magnus, Duke of Saxony (b. 1045)

entities.title: Magnus, Duke of Saxony
entities.description: Magnus was the duke of Saxony from 1072 to 1106. Eldest son and successor of Ordulf and Wulfhild of Norway, he was the last member of the House of Billung.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emperor Rokujō of Japan (b. 1164)

entities.title: Emperor Rokujō
entities.description: Emperor Rokujō  was the 79th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession. His reign spanned the years from 1165 through 1168.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Wallace, Scottish rebel commander (b. 1272)

entities.title: William Wallace
entities.description: Sir William Wallace was a Scottish knight who became one of the main leaders during the First War of Scottish Independence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolaas Zannekin, Flemish peasant leader (in the battle of Cassel)

entities.title: Nicolaas Zannekin
entities.description: Nicolaas Zannekin, was a Flemish peasant leader, best known for his role in the Peasant revolt in Flanders 1323–28.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick IV, Duke of Lorraine (b. 1282)

entities.title: Frederick IV, Duke of Lorraine
entities.description: Frederick IV, called the Fighter, was the Duke of Lorraine from 1312 to his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heilwige Bloemardinne, Christian mystic (b. c. 1265)

entities.title: Heilwige Bloemardinne
entities.description: Heilwige Bloemardinne was a Christian mystic who lived in Brussels and was loosely associated with the Brethren of the Free Spirit. She was also known as Heilwijch Blomart.

heading: Deaths
txt: John de Stratford, Archbishop of Canterbury

entities.title: John de Stratford
entities.description: John de Stratford was Archbishop of Canterbury, Bishop of Winchester, Treasurer and Chancellor of England.

entities.title: Archbishop of Canterbury
entities.description: The Archbishop of Canterbury is the senior bishop and principal leader of the Church of England, the symbolic head of the worldwide Anglican Communion and the diocesan bishop of the Diocese of Canterbury. The current archbishop is Justin Welby, who was enthroned at Canterbury Cathedral on 21 March 2013. Welby is the 105th in a line which goes back more than 1400 years to Augustine of Canterbury, t

heading: Deaths
txt: Chen Youliang, founder of the Dahan regime (b. 1320)

entities.title: Chen Youliang
entities.description: Chen Youliang was the founder and first emperor of the Chen Han (陈汉) or Da Han, a state in the late Yuan Dynasty and early Ming dynasty of Chinese history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gil Álvarez Carrillo de Albornoz, Spanish cardinal (b. 1310)

entities.title: Gil Álvarez Carrillo de Albornoz
entities.description: Gil Álvarez Carrillo de Albornoz more commonly Gil de Albornoz, was a Spanish cardinal, archbishop, Chancellor of Toledo and ecclesiastical leader. He was a descendant of the kings of León and Aragón and founder of the Collegio di Spagna, an academic institution of Bologna.

heading: Deaths
txt: Olaf II of Denmark (b. 1370)

entities.title: Olaf II of Denmark
entities.description: Olaf II of Denmark was King of Denmark as Olaf II from 1376 and King of Norway as Olaf IV from 1380 until his death. Olaf was the son of Queen Margaret I of Denmark and King Haakon VI of Norway, and grandson of kings Magnus IV of Sweden and Valdemar IV of Denmark.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johannes Pullois, Franco-Flemish composer (b. c. 1420?)

entities.title: Johannes Pullois
entities.description: Johannes Pullois was a Franco-Flemish composer of the Renaissance, active in both the Low Countries and Italy. He was one of the early generation of composers to carry the Franco-Flemish polyphonic style from its home region in the Netherlands to Italy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas de Littleton, English judge and legal author (b. c. 1407)

entities.title: Thomas de Littleton
entities.description: Sir Thomas de Littleton or de Lyttleton KB was an English judge and legal writer from the Lyttelton family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isabella of Aragon, Queen of Portugal, eldest daughter of Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon (b. 1470)

entities.title: Isabella of Aragon, Queen of Portugal
entities.description: Isabella, Princess of Asturias was a queen consort of Portugal and heir presumptive of King Ferdinand II of Aragon and Queen Isabella I of Castile, as their eldest daughter. Her younger siblings were John, Prince of Asturias, Queen Joanna I of Castile, Maria, Queen of Portugal and Catherine, Queen of England.

entities.title: Isabella I of Castile
entities.description: Isabella I was Queen of Castile from 1474 and, as the wife of King Ferdinand II, King of Aragon from 1479 until her death, reigning over a dynastically unified Spain jointly with her husband Ferdinand; together they would be known as the Catholic Monarchs. Isabella is considered the first Queen of Spain de facto, being described as such during her own lifetime, although Castile and Aragon de jure

entities.title: Ferdinand II of Aragon
entities.description: Ferdinand II was King of Aragon from 1479 to his death. As the husband of Queen Isabella I of Castile, he was King of Castile from 1474 to 1504 as Ferdinand V. He reigned over a dynastically unified Spain jointly with Isabella; together they are known as the Catholic Monarchs. Ferdinand is considered de facto the first king of Spain, being described as such during his own lifetime, although Castil

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Molinet, French poet and composer (b. 1435)

entities.title: Jean Molinet
entities.description: Jean Molinet was a French poet, chronicler, and composer. He is best remembered for his prose translation of Roman de la rose.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philibert Berthelier, Swiss soldier (b. 1465)

entities.title: Philibert Berthelier (Geneva patriot)
entities.description: Philibert Berthelier, often known just as Berthelier, was a Genevan patriot, an uncompromising enemy of the Duke of Savoy in his ambition to control Geneva.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guillaume Budé, French philosopher and scholar (b. 1467)

entities.title: Guillaume Budé
entities.description: Guillaume Budé was a French scholar and humanist. He was involved in the founding of Collegium Trilingue, which later became the Collège de France. Budé was also the first keeper of the royal library at the Palace of Fontainebleau, which was later moved to Paris, where it became the Bibliothèque nationale de France. He was an ambassador to Rome and held several important judicial and civil adminis

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Wharton, 1st Baron Wharton (b. 1495)

entities.title: Thomas Wharton, 1st Baron Wharton
entities.description: Thomas Wharton, 1st Baron Wharton was an English nobleman and a follower of King Henry VIII of England. He is best known for his victory at Solway Moss on 24 November 1542 for which he was given a barony.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ebussuud Efendi, Turkish lawyer and jurist (b. 1490)

entities.title: Ebussuud Efendi
entities.description: Ebussuud Efendi was a Hanafi Maturidi Ottoman jurist and Qur'an exegete. He was also called "El-İmâdî" because his family was from Imâd, a village near Iskilip.

heading: Deaths
txt: Luis de León, Spanish poet and academic (b. 1527)

entities.title: Luis de León
entities.description: Luis de León, was a Spanish lyric poet, Augustinian friar, theologian and academic, active during the Spanish Golden Age.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gerbrand Adriaenszoon Bredero, Dutch poet and playwright (b. 1585)

entities.title: Gerbrand Adriaenszoon Bredero
entities.description: Gerbrand Adriaenszoon Bredero was a Dutch poet and playwright in the period known as the Dutch Golden Age.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham, English politician, Lord Lieutenant of Buckinghamshire (b. 1592)

entities.title: George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham
entities.description: George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham, KG (; 28 August 1592 – 23 August 1628), was an English courtier, statesman, and patron of the arts. He was a favourite and possibly also a lover of King James I of England. Buckingham remained at the height of royal favour for the first three years of the reign of James' son, King Charles I, until a disgruntled army officer assassinated him.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Buckinghamshire
entities.description: There has been a Lord Lieutenant of Buckinghamshire almost continuously since the position was created by King Henry VIII in 1535. The only exception to this was the English Civil War and English Interregnum between 1643 and 1660 when there was no king to support the Lieutenancy. The following list consists of all known holders of the position: earlier records have been lost and so a complete list

heading: Deaths
txt: John Byron, 1st Baron Byron, English soldier and politician (b. 1600)

entities.title: John Byron, 1st Baron Byron
entities.description: John Byron, 1st Baron Byron KB was an English nobleman, Royalist, politician, peer, knight, and supporter of Charles I during the English Civil War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Nott, English politician, Colonial Governor of Virginia (b. 1654)

entities.title: Edward Nott
entities.description: Colonel Edward Nott, Esq. was a British Colonial Governor of Virginia. He was appointed by Queen Anne on either April 25, 1705 or August 15, 1705. His administration lasted only one year, as he died in 1706 at the age of 49. He is interred at Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, Virginia. He is noted as having been a "mild, benevolent man."

entities.title: Colonial Governor of Virginia
entities.description: This is a list of colonial governors of Virginia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Increase Mather, American minister and author (b. 1639)

entities.title: Increase Mather
entities.description: Increase Mather was an American Puritan clergyman in the Massachusetts Bay Colony and president of Harvard College for twenty years (1681–1701). He was influential in the administration of the colony during a time that coincided with the notorious Salem witch trials.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb, French physicist and engineer (b. 1736)

entities.title: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb
entities.description: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb was a French military engineer and physicist. He is best known as the eponymous discoverer of what is now called Coulomb's law, the description of the electrostatic force of attraction and repulsion, though he also did important work on friction.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Wilson (ornithologist), Scottish-American poet, ornithologist, and illustrator (b. 1766)

entities.title: Alexander Wilson (ornithologist)
entities.description: Alexander Wilson was a Scottish-American poet, ornithologist, naturalist, and illustrator. Identified by George Ord as the "Father of American Ornithology", Wilson is regarded as the greatest American ornithologist prior to Audubon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Oliver Hazard Perry, American commander (b. 1785)

entities.title: Oliver Hazard Perry
entities.description:
Oliver Hazard Perry was an American naval commander, born in South Kingstown, Rhode Island. As the best-known and most prominent member
of the Perry family naval dynasty, he was the son of Sarah Wallace Alexander and United States Navy Captain Christopher Raymond Perry, and older brother of Commodore Matthew C. Perry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferenc Kazinczy, Hungarian author and poet (b. 1759)

entities.title: Ferenc Kazinczy
entities.description: Ferenc Kazinczy was a Hungarian author, poet, translator, neologist, the most indefatigable agent in the regeneration of the Hungarian language and literature at the turn of the 19th century. Today his name is connected with the extensive Language Reform of the 19th century, when thousands of words were coined or revived, enabling the Hungarian language to keep up with scientific progress and beco

heading: Deaths
txt: August Neidhardt von Gneisenau, Prussian field marshal (b. 1760)

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Calder, American lawyer and politician (b. 1806)

entities.title: Alexander Calder (Beaumont, Texas)
entities.description: Alexander Calder was the first mayor of Beaumont, Texas, on August 8, 1840.

heading: Deaths
txt: Auguste-Marseille Barthélemy, French poet and author (b. 1796)

entities.title: Auguste-Marseille Barthélemy
entities.description: Auguste-Marseille Barthélemy, born at Marseilles, was a French satirical poet. His name can hardly be separated from that of his friend and compatriot, Joseph Méry (1798–1866), with whom he carried on so intimate a collaboration that it is not possible to distinguish their personalities in their joint works.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Thompson, British boxer (b. 1811)

entities.title: William Thompson (boxer)
entities.description: William Abednego "Bendigo" Thompson was an English bare-knuckle boxer who won the heavyweight championship of England from James Burke on 12 February 1839. He was inducted into The Ring magazine Hall of Fame in 1955, the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 1991 and the Bare Knuckle Boxing Hall of Fame in 2011.

heading: Deaths
txt: Deodoro da Fonseca, Brazilian field marshal and politician, 1st President of Brazil (b. 1827)

entities.title: Deodoro da Fonseca
entities.description: Manuel Deodoro da Fonseca was a Brazilian politician and military officer who served as the 1st president of Brazil. He took office after heading a military coup that deposed Emperor Pedro II and proclaimed the Republic in 1889, disestablishing the Empire, and stepped down little more than two years later, in 1891, under great political pressure. He is therefore the first Brazilian President to ha

entities.title: President of Brazil
entities.description: The president of Brazil, officially the President of the Federative Republic of Brazil or simply the President of the Republic, is both the head of state and the head of government of Brazil. The president leads the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the Brazilian Armed Forces. The presidential system was established in 1889, upon the proclamation of the re

heading: Deaths
txt: Kuroda Kiyotaka, Japanese general and politician, 2nd Prime Minister of Japan (b. 1840)

entities.title: Kuroda Kiyotaka
entities.description: Count Kuroda Kiyotaka , also known as Kuroda Ryōsuke , was a Japanese politician of the Meiji era. He was Prime Minister of Japan from 1888 to 1889. He was also vice chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi).

entities.title: Prime Minister of Japan
entities.description: The prime minister of Japan  is head of the government of Japan, the chief executive of the National Cabinet and the commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Japan; he is appointed by the emperor of Japan after being designated by the National Diet and must enjoy the confidence of the House of Representatives to remain in office. He is the head of the Cabinet and appoints and dismisses the other

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich Berté, Slovak-Austrian composer (b. 1856)

entities.title: Heinrich Berté
entities.description: Heinrich Berté, born Heinrich Bettelheim was an Austria-Hungarian composer of operas and operettas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rudolph Valentino, Italian actor (b. 1895)

entities.title: Rudolph Valentino
entities.description:
Rodolfo Alfonso Raffaello Pierre Filiberto Guglielmi di Valentina d'Antonguella, known professionally as Rudolph Valentino, was an Italian actor based in the United States who starred in several well-known silent films including The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, The Sheik, Blood and Sand, The Eagle, 
and The Son of the Sheik.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicola Sacco, Italian anarchist convicted of murder (b. 1891)

entities.title: Nicola Sacco
entities.description: Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were Italian immigrant anarchists who were controversially convicted of murdering a guard and a paymaster during the April 15, 1920, armed robbery of the Slater and Morrill Shoe Company in Braintree, Massachusetts, United States. Seven years later, they were electrocuted in the electric chair at Charlestown State Prison.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bartolomeo Vanzetti, Italian anarchist convicted of murder (b. 1888)

heading: Deaths
txt: Adolf Loos, Austrian architect and theoretician, designed Villa Müller (b. 1870)

entities.title: Adolf Loos
entities.description:
Adolf Franz Karl Viktor Maria Loos
(German pronunciation: [ˈaːdɔlf loːs]; 10 December 1870 – 23 August 1933) was an Austrian architect and influential European theorist of modern architecture. His essay Ornament and Crime advocated smooth and clear surfaces in contrast to the lavish decorations of the fin de siècle, as well as the more modern aesthetic principles of the Vienna Secession, exemplifi

entities.title: Villa Müller
entities.description: The Villa Müller is a Modernist villa in Prague, Czech Republic built in 1930. It was designed by Adolf Loos as a residence for František Müller, co-owner of the Kapsa-Müller construction company from Pilsen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Roussel, French composer and educator (b. 1869)

entities.title: Albert Roussel
entities.description: Albert Charles Paul Marie Roussel was a French composer. He spent seven years as a midshipman, turned to music as an adult, and became one of the most prominent French composers of the interwar period. His early works were strongly influenced by the impressionism of Debussy and Ravel, while he later turned toward neoclassicism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdülmecid II, Ottoman sultan (b. 1868)

entities.title: Abdülmecid II
entities.description: Abdulmejid II was the last Caliph of the Ottoman Dynasty, the first and the last Caliph of the Republic of Turkey, nominally the 37th Head of the Ottoman Imperial House from 1922 to 1924.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stefan Filipkiewicz, Polish painter and illustrator (b. 1879)

heading: Deaths
txt: Helen Churchill Candee, American geographer, journalist, and author (b. 1858)

entities.title: Helen Churchill Candee
entities.description: Helen Churchill Candee was an American author, journalist, interior decorator, feminist, and geographer. Today, she is best known as a survivor of the sinking of RMS Titanic in 1912, and for her later work as a travel writer and explorer of southeast Asia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jaan Sarv, Estonian mathematician and scholar (b. 1877)

entities.title: Jaan Sarv
entities.description: Jaan Sarv was an Estonian mathematician and educator. Most of his life he worked as a professor at the University of Tartu. Sarv laid the foundation of Estonian language mathematical education.

heading: Deaths
txt: Oscar Hammerstein II, American director, producer, and composer (b. 1895)

entities.title: Oscar Hammerstein II
entities.description: Oscar Greeley Clendenning Hammerstein II was an American lyricist, librettist, theatrical producer, and director in the musical theater for almost 40 years. He won eight Tony Awards and two Academy Awards for Best Original Song. Many of his songs are standard repertoire for vocalists and jazz musicians. He co-wrote 850 songs.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Anderson, Russian-German ethnologist and academic (b. 1885)

entities.title: Walter Anderson (folklorist)
entities.description: Walter Arthur Alexander Anderson was a Baltic German ethnologist (folklorist) and numismatist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hoot Gibson, American actor, director, and producer (b. 1892)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmond Hogan, Australian politician, 30th Premier of Victoria (b. 1883)

entities.title: Edmond Hogan
entities.description: Edmond John "Ned" Hogan was an Australian politician who was the 30th Premier of Victoria. He was born in Wallace, Victoria, where his Irish-born parents were small farmers. After attending a Roman Catholic primary school, he became a farm worker and then a timber worker, and spent some time on the goldfields of Western Australia.

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis X. Bushman, American actor, director, and screenwriter (b. 1883)

entities.title: Francis X. Bushman
entities.description: Francis Xavier Bushman was an American film actor and director. His career as a matinee idol started in 1911 in the silent film His Friend's Wife. He gained a large female following and was one of the biggest stars of the 1910s and early 1920s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georges Berger, Belgian race car driver (b. 1918)

entities.title: Georges Berger
entities.description: Georges Berger was a racing driver who raced a Gordini in his two World Championship Formula One Grands Prix.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nathaniel Cartmell, American runner and coach (b. 1883)

heading: Deaths
txt: Roberto Assagioli, Italian psychiatrist and author (b. 1888)

entities.title: Roberto Assagioli
entities.description: Roberto Assagioli was an Italian psychiatrist and pioneer in the fields of humanistic and transpersonal psychology. Assagioli founded the psychological movement known as psychosynthesis, which is still being developed today by therapists and psychologists, who practice the psychological methods and techniques he developed. His work, expounded in two books and many monographs published as pamphlets

heading: Deaths
txt: Faruk Gürler, Turkish general (b. 1913)

entities.title: Faruk Gürler
entities.description: Ömer Faruk Gürler was a Turkish general. He was the Commander of the Turkish Army during the 1971 Turkish coup d'état, and then Chief of the General Staff of Turkey. He was the military's candidate in the 1973 Presidential election, but lost to Fahri Korutürk.

heading: Deaths
txt: Naum Gabo, Russian sculptor and academic (b. 1890)

entities.title: Naum Gabo
entities.description: Naum Gabo, born Naum Neemia Pevsner, was an influential sculptor, theorist, and key figure in Russia's post-Revolution avant-garde and the subsequent development of twentieth-century sculpture. His work combined geometric abstraction with a dynamic organization of form in small reliefs and constructions, monumental public sculpture and pioneering kinetic works that assimilated new materials such a

heading: Deaths
txt: Stanford Moore, American biochemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1913)

entities.title: Stanford Moore
entities.description: Stanford Moore was an American biochemist. He shared a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1972 (with Christian B. Anfinsen and William Howard Stein, for work done at Rockefeller University on the structure of the enzyme ribonuclease and for contributing to the understanding of the connection between the chemical structure and catalytic activity of the ribonuclease molecule.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Didier Pironi, French race car and boat driver (b. 1952)

entities.title: Didier Pironi
entities.description: Didier Joseph Louis Pironi was a French racing driver. During his career he competed in 72 Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, driving for Tyrrell (1978–1979), Ligier (1980) and Ferrari (1981–1982), his F1 career ending after a practice crash at the 1982 German Grand Prix. He won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1978 driving a Renault Alpine A442B.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mohammed Abed Elhai, Sudanese poet and academic (b. 1944)

entities.title: Mohammed Abed Elhai
entities.description: Mohammed Abdul-Hayy or Muhammad Abd al-Hayy was a member of the first generation of post-colonial Sudanese writers and academics. Together with Ali El-Mak and Salah Ahmed Ibrahim, he is regarded as a pioneer of modern poetry in Sudan.

heading: Deaths
txt: R. D. Laing, Scottish psychiatrist and author (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: David Rose, American pianist and composer (b. 1910)

entities.title: David Rose (songwriter)
entities.description: David Daniel Rose was an American songwriter, composer, arranger, pianist, and orchestra leader. His best known compositions were "The Stripper", "Holiday for Strings", and "Calypso Melody". He also wrote music for many television series, including It's a Great Life, The Tony Martin Show, Little House on the Prairie, Highway to Heaven, Bonanza, Leave it to Beaver, and Highway Patrol, some under th

heading: Deaths
txt: Zoltán Fábri, Hungarian director and screenwriter (b. 1917)

entities.title: Zoltán Fábri
entities.description: Zoltán Fábri was a Hungarian film director and screenwriter. His films The Boys of Paul Street (1969) and Hungarians (1978) were nominated for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. His 1965 film Twenty Hours shared the Grand Prix with War and Peace at the 4th Moscow International Film Festival. His 1969 film The Toth Family was entered into the 7th Moscow International Film Festival. H

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Eisenstaedt, German-American photographer and journalist (b. 1898)

entities.title: Alfred Eisenstaedt
entities.description: Alfred Eisenstaedt was a German-born American photographer and photojournalist. He began his career in Germany prior to World War II but achieved prominence as a staff photographer for Life magazine after moving to the U.S. Life featured more than 90 of his pictures on its covers, and more than 2,500 of his photo stories were published.

heading: Deaths
txt: Margaret Tucker, Australian author and activist (b. 1904)

entities.title: Margaret Tucker
entities.description: Margaret Lilardia Tucker MBE was an Aboriginal Australian activist and writer. She was among the first Aboriginal authors to publish an autobiography, in 1977.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric Gairy, Grenadian educator and politician, 1st Prime Minister of Grenada (b. 1922)

entities.title: Eric Gairy
entities.description: Sir Eric Matthew Gairy PC was the first Prime Minister of Grenada, serving from his country's independence in 1974 until his overthrow in a coup by Maurice Bishop in 1979. Gairy also served as head of government in pre-independence Grenada as Chief Minister from 1961 to 1962, and as Premier from 1967 to 1974.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Grenada
entities.description: This is a list of heads of government of Grenada, from the establishment of the office of Chief Minister in 1960 to the present day.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Kendrew, English biochemist and crystallographer, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1917)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Norman Wexler, American screenwriter (b. 1926)

entities.title: Norman Wexler
entities.description: Norman Wexler was an American screenwriter whose work included films such as Saturday Night Fever, Serpico and Joe. A New Bedford native and 1944 Central High School graduate in Detroit, Wexler attended Harvard University before moving to New York in 1951.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Anthony Kaiser, American priest and missionary (b. 1932)

entities.title: John Anthony Kaiser
entities.description: John Anthony Kaiser was a Roman Catholic priest and Mill Hill father from Perham, Minnesota, US, who was assassinated near his mission at Morendat, in western Kenya.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kathleen Freeman, American actress (b. 1919)

entities.title: Kathleen Freeman
entities.description: Kathleen Freeman was an American film, television, voice and stage actress. In a career that spanned more than 50 years, she portrayed acerbic maids, secretaries, teachers, busybodies, nurses, and battle-axe neighbors and relatives, almost invariably to comic effect. In film she is perhaps best remembered for appearing in 11 Jerry Lewis comedies in the 1950s and 60s, The Blues Brothers (1980) and

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Maas, American journalist and author (b. 1929)

heading: Deaths
txt: Hoyt Wilhelm, American baseball player and coach (b. 1922)

entities.title: Hoyt Wilhelm
entities.description: James Hoyt Wilhelm, nicknamed "Old Sarge", was an American Major League Baseball pitcher with the New York Giants, St. Louis Cardinals, Cleveland Indians, Baltimore Orioles, Chicago White Sox, California Angels, Atlanta Braves, Chicago Cubs, and Los Angeles Dodgers between 1952 and 1972. Wilhelm was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1985, and is one of 83 pitchers enshrined in the Hall.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bobby Bonds, American baseball player and manager (b. 1946)

entities.title: Bobby Bonds
entities.description: Bobby Lee Bonds was an American right fielder in Major League Baseball from 1968 to 1981, primarily with the San Francisco Giants. Noted for his outstanding combination of power hitting and speed, he was the first player to have more than two seasons of 30 home runs and 30 stolen bases, doing so a record five times, and was the first to accomplish the feat in both major leagues; he became the seco

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Dyer, Australian footballer and coach (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jan Sedivka, Czech-Australian violinist and educator (b. 1917)

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Kijana Wamalwa, Kenyan lawyer and politician, 8th Vice President of Kenya (b. 1944)

entities.title: Vice President of Kenya
entities.description: The Deputy President of Kenya is the second-highest executive official in the Kenyan government. The Deputy President is the principal assistant of the President and deputises for the President in executive functions. Prior to the 2010 Constitution of Kenya, the Deputy President was known as the Vice President. While the Vice President was appointed by the President, the Deputy President is electe

heading: Deaths
txt: Brock Peters, American actor (b. 1927)

entities.title: Brock Peters
entities.description: Brock Peters was an American actor and singer, best known for playing the role of Tom Robinson in the 1962 film To Kill a Mockingbird and for his role as the villainous "Crown" in the 1959 film version of Porgy and Bess. In later years, he gained recurring roles in the Star Trek franchise portraying Starfleet Admiral Cartwright in two of the Star Trek feature films and Joseph Sisko, father of Benj

heading: Deaths
txt: Maynard Ferguson, Canadian trumpet player and bandleader (b. 1928)

entities.title: Maynard Ferguson
entities.description: Walter Maynard Ferguson CM was a Canadian jazz trumpeter and bandleader. He came to prominence in Stan Kenton's orchestra before forming his own big band in 1957. He was noted for his bands, which often served as stepping stones for up-and-coming talent, his versatility on several instruments, and his ability to play in a high register.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerry Nelson, American puppeteer and voice actor (b. 1934)

entities.title: Jerry Nelson
entities.description: Jerry L. Nelson was an American puppeteer, best known for his work with The Muppets. Renowned for his wide range of characters and singing abilities, he performed Muppet characters on Sesame Street, The Muppet Show, Fraggle Rock, and various Muppet movies and specials.

txt: Richard J. Corman, American businessman, founded the R.J. Corman Railroad Group (b. 1955)

entities.title: Richard J. Corman
entities.description: Richard Jay Corman was the founder and owner of R. J. Corman Railroad Group, a Nicholasville, Kentucky-based railroad services and short line operating company.

entities.title: R.J. Corman Railroad Group
entities.description: R.J. Corman Railroad Group, LLC is a privately owned railroad services and short line operating company headquartered in Nicholasville, KY, with field locations in 23 states. It was owned by Richard J. Corman, who established the company in 1973, and ran it until his death on August 23, 2013. The company owns eleven short-line railroads spanning Indiana, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, Ohio

txt: Augusta Chiwy, Congolese-Belgian nurse (b. 1921)

entities.title: Augusta Chiwy
entities.description: Augusta Marie Chiwy was a Belgian nurse who served as a volunteer during the Siege of Bastogne in 1944. She worked with U.S. Army physician John Prior and with fellow Belgian nurse Renée Lemaire, treating injured soldiers during the Battle of the Bulge.
